awd_titl_txt: New Solution-Processable Phthalocyanine Derivatives with Near-Infrared Absorbing Condensed Phase Morphologies: Application to Organic Solar Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project jointly funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Division of Chemistry (CHE) and the Electronic and Photonic Materials program of the Division of Materials Research (DMR), Professor Dominic McGrath of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Arizona will develop new classes of phthalocyanine dyes with interesting optoelectronic properties. The goal of this research is to exploit the properties of these dyes in new optoelectronic devices, particularly solution processable solar energy technologies, which may ultimately be produced in a fashion that is low cost, and with a scalability that meaningfully contributes to the sustainability of our planet. This research program has elements of molecular design, synthesis, characterization, and investigation of condensed phased materials properties, and as such will provide a multidimensional vehicle for training of scientists from all levels, including those from students underrepresented in the STEM fields.  Outreach activities to K-12 and community college students are also planned.  

Phthalocyanine chromophores display a combination of long wavelength absorbance, photochemical stability, and photoconductivity, making them useful for solar transduction technologies such as organic solar cells.  The proposed synthesis develops a new class of phthalocyanines intended to develop a fundamental understanding between molecular structure and condensed phase (i.e. thin film) properties such as charge mobility and light absorption.  In this project, four classes of new phthalocyanine chromophores will be prepared to answer the following questions: 1) Can a C2-symmetrical phthalocyanine molecular structure provide solution processibility while maintaining condensed phase close molecular overlap known to be critical to near-infrared spectral response and high charge mobility? 2) Can the material energetics, critical for maintaining vectorial charge transport and high open-circuit photovoltages, be predictably modulated based on structural elements? 3) Will the condensed phase properties of these materials, when appropriately optimized, translate to viability as materials for solar-electric conversion in device platforms with appropriate acceptor molecules?
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Dominic McGrath of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Arizona developed new classes of phthalocyanine (Pc) dyes with interesting optoelectronic properties.  The goal of this research was to determine the properties of these dyes relevant to their use in new optoelectronic devices, particularly solution processable solar energy technologies, which may ultimately be produced in a fashion that is low cost, and with a scalability that meaningfully contributes to the sustainability of our planet.  These studies successfully helped establish a new class of organic semiconducting materials that have potential applications in organic electronic and energy conversion technologies.

A. Intellectual Merit: Pc chromophores display a combination of long wavelength absorbance, photochemical stability, and photoconductivity, making them useful for solar transduction technologies such as organic solar cells.  The developed materials are a new class of Pcs intended to provide a fundamental understanding between molecular structure and condensed phase (i.e. thin film) properties such as charge mobility and light absorption.  Several variants of this new class of Pc chromophores, christened ?rigid side-strapped phthalocyanines? (RSS-Pcs)   were prepared and structurally characterized.  We have successfully carried out our plans to (a) develop general synthetic routes to RSS-Pcs as detailed in our design principles; (b) modulate structural elements of the RSS-Pcs including side-chain substituents, aromatic bridging groups, and metal center; (c) investigate energetics, crystalline packing, and their influence on optical properties; and (d) measure charge carrier mobilities.  Our molecular design as initially postulated was predica?ted on the incorporation of tri-/tetra?valent metal centers into the Pc chromophores so that the dipolar and non-planar nature of the MPc structure would induce long range ?tape-like? aggregation in the condensed phase.  But it has become clear from the results of the research, including the solution aggre?ga?tion, thin-film spectrophoto?metric, and XRD studies, that (1) even divalent RSS-ZnPcs adopt polymorphs with J-aggregation similar to that of the RSS-TiOPcs, seemingly negating the neces?sity for tri-/tetravalent metal centers with the dipolar orga?niz?ing force of their apical ligands, suggesting that the staggered co-facial architectures are inherent to the RSS-Pc scaffold design; and (2) there is evidence of a correlation between structural modifications, some quite subtle, and resultant molecular packing and measured charge mobility.  In addition, we have discovered (a) new applications of particular Pc materials in perovskite solar cells (PSCs); and (b) a green oxidation method for pyrene derivatives. 

B. Broader Impact: Since this research program was a coherent combination of molecular design, synthesis, characterization, and investigation of condensed phased materials properties, this work provided an excellent vehicle for training of scientist from all levels, including those from students underrepresented in the STEM fields.  Co-workers in this research program obtained a broad array of experience and training in molecular design, synthesis, and characterization, with important considerations of organic reactivity.  All students involved in this project have received training in laboratory safety, research ethics, good laboratory practice, communica?tion by oral and written methods, and presentation skills.  NSF funding has helped support 1 postdoctoral fellow, 4 graduate students, and 10 undergraduate co-workers in the PI?s laboratories under the auspices of this award.  Outreach activities involved K-12 students and students at a community college.  The PI established relationships with Borton Primary Magnet School and the Tucson Village Farm, at which science concepts (e.g. solids/liquids/gases, hydrophilic/hydrophobic, solutions/suspensions) have been demonstrated to the classrooms four times yearly.  Students at Yavapai Community College (Prescott, AZ) were involved the research in a remote capacity, preparing precursor materials for use in the PI?s lab. 


Last Modified: 11/30/2020
Modified by: Dominic V Mcgrath
